[[User:Tiamut|Tiamut]][[User_talk:Tiamut|talk]] 18:34, 21 August 2011 (UTC) === Arguments for the identification of Baca with Bakkah or Mecca=== The names "Baca" and "Bakkah" are almost identical. If Bakkah is Mecca, then in accordance with Muslim beliefs that Mecca is [[God in Islam|God's]] [[Holy city|select city]]. Also, in the Biblical [[Book of Isaiah]], several passages provide descriptions of [[Zion]], several of which, notably [[Isaiah]] 35:8-10,{{bibleverse||Isaiah|35:8-35:10|KJV}}, King James Version which states that the "unclean" will not enter the city, and 60:16-18,{{bibleverse||Isaiah|60:16-60:18|KJV}}, King James Version which describes its prosperity, bear striking resemblance to Mecca in Muslim eyes with the fact that small birds constantly circle the Kabba and build nests in the open mosque, where people circle the House with praise and prayer constantly and the historic well in Mecca associated with Ishmael and [[Hagar (Bible)|Hagar]] ([[Islamic view of Hagar|Hājar]]) referred to in the [[Book of Genesis]]{{bibleverse||Genesis|21:14-21:21|KJV}} is a bow shot away. {{Quote|Blessed are those whose strength is in you, who have set their hearts on pilgrimage.|Bible, Psalm 85, verse 5{{bibleverse||Psalms|84:5|NIV}}, [[New International Version]]}} {{Quote|Makkah is a place of Pilgrimage, thousands make it every year|Arabic; ''[[hajj]]'', Hebrew; ''mes-il-law''}} {{Quote|As they pass through the Valley of Baca,|Bible, Psalm 84, verse 6{{bibleverse||Psalms|84:6|NIV}}, New International Version}} Some Bible versions say "Valley of Tears/Weeping",{{bibleverse||Psalms|84:6|AB}}, [[Amplified Bible]]; {{bibleverse||Psalms|84:6|ASV}}, [[American Standard Version]]; {{bibleverse||Psalms|84:6|NASB}}, [[New American Standard Bible]]; {{bibleverse||Psalms|84:6|NLT}}, [[New Living Translation]]; {{bibleverse||Psalms|84:6|YLT}}, [[Young's Literal Translation]]. this would make more sense since Ishmael and Hagar cried (baka’) to God for aid in the wilderness after Abraham left them in a deserted area. In Hebrew "tears" is Baka’ and in Arabic Baka’ means to cry. Another note to look into is that many places named in the Bible are not necessarily found/match or proven historically. {{Quote|they make it a place of springs; the autumn rains also cover it with pools.|Bible, Psalm 84, verse 6}} The [[Zamzam Well]] is a spring that [[Muslim history|Islamic history]] states came into being at the time of Ishmael and Hagar. The spring's existence was revealed by the [[angel]] [[Gabriel]] ([[Holy Spirit (Islam)|Jibral]]) after Hagar had "cried" to God for aid.{{cite web | title=The Well of Zam zam | work=IslamOnline | author=Shil, Mahmoud Isma`il & `Abdul-Wahid, `Abdur-Rahman |url=http://www.islamonline.net/English/hajj/Landmarks/1425/08.shtml| accessdate=2005-06-06 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20051127041248/http://www.islamonline.net/English/hajj/Landmarks/1425/08.shtml |archivedate = 2005-11-27}} {{Quote|And the angel of the LORD found her by a fountain of water in the wilderness, by the fountain in the way to Shur.|Bible, Book of Genesis 16, verse 7{{bibleverse||Genesis|16:7|KJV}}}} {{Quote|They go from strength to strength, every one of them in Zion appeareth before God.|Bible, Psalm 84, verse 7{{bibleverse||Psalms|84:7|KJV}}}} === Arguments against the identification of Baca with Mecca === 1. The passage itself pins the location of the pilgrimage to which Psalms 84 refers. Psalms 84:7 They go from strength to strength, [every one of them] in Zion appeareth before God. Zion, the name of the [[Mount Zion|easternmost hill]] of ancient [[Jerusalem]], is mentioned 153 times in the [[Authorized King James Version|King James Version]] of the Bible.[http://www.blueletterbible.org/search/translationResults.cfm?Criteria=zion&t=KJV Zion occurs 153 times in 153 verses in the KJV] [[Tanakh|Jewish scriptures]] apply the term "Mount Zion" to the [[Temple Mount]] or the [[City of David]], both located on this elevation. For [[Jews]] the term "Zion" became a [[synecdoche]] referring to the entire city of Jerusalem and the [[Land of Israel]]. Thus this passage describes a pilgrimage to Jerusalem in the [[Holy Land]] rather than one to Mecca 2. There is no historical or archaeological record of the Jews to whom this passage refers, going on pilgrimage to any temple, other than the one they themselves [[Temple in Jerusalem|built in Jerusalem]]. 3. Zion - that is Jerusalem - lies {{convert|1200|km|abbr=on}} across the [[Arabian Desert]] from Mecca. 4. According to the study from [[Dr. Rafat Amari]] shows that there is no historical record penned before the 4th century, that suggests that Mecca ever existed before that time, while other ancient [[Arabian Peninsula|Arabian]] towns are well attested in the historical record.[http://religionresearchinstitute.org/mecca/classical.htm Studies by Classical Writers Show That Mecca Could Not Have Been Built Before the 4th Century A.D.] 5. In a study conducted by Dr. Rafat Amari, there is no archaeological record that suggests that Mecca ever existed before the 4th century, while other [[Ancient Towns in Saudi Arabia|ancient Arabian towns]] are well attested, in the archaeological record.[http://religionresearchinstitute.org/mecca/archeology.htm The History and Archaeology of Arabia Show that Mecca Did Not Exist Before the Advent of Christianity.] 6. In another study, Dr. Rafat Amari found that no pre-4th century historical or archaeological record that suggests that the Kaaba existed before the early 5th century.[http://religionresearchinstitute.org/mecca/construction.htm The True Story of the Construction of the Temple of Mecca] 7. Pilgrimages to Zion - to Jerusalem - to the Holy Land - were conducted during the [[Solomon's Temple|First Temple Period]].{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} 8. Baca is a Hebrew name that dates to before 1000 BC of a valley in [[Palestine]], and is also a Hebrew term for balsam or mulberry trees that "weep" or bleed sap when they are cut. Bakkah is a more modern language 7th century AD [[Quraysh (tribe)|Quraysh]] [[Varieties of Arabic|Arabic dialect]] name that some suggest refers to Mecca.[http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=56&letter=B&search=Valley%20of%20Baca Baca, The Valley of:] from the [[Jewish Encyclopedia]][http://net.bible.org/dictionary.php?word=Baca Baca at Net Bible] 9. Genesis 16 verse 7 also pins its own location in "Shur", which is located in the northern Sinai Peninsula, on the north-eastern border of Egypt.
